questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, cold, and respiratory rate was 46/min. According to the WHO guidelines, which of the following, if present, is not considered a danger sign in this baby?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it can be inferred that the child has pneumonia. Chest indrawing is not considered a danger sign in this baby.

 Danger signs of pneumonia in children are: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • Persistent vomiting 
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious 
  • Stridor in a calm child 
  • Severe malnutrition 

 Pneumonia is usually associated with tachypnea (increased respiratory rate). Fast breathing is defined according to age groups as:

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months  >60 breaths/min
2-12 months  >50 breaths/min
1-5 years  >40 breaths/min

 The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia- with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia- pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and polyhydramnios.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign if done before orogastric tube decompression. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble /single bubble. It is seen at 2-8 weeks of life, more commonly in boys. It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting which can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Visible gastric peristalsis can also be observed.

Option B: Jejunal atresia on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign. It is the most common type of gastrointestinal atresia. Presenting features include bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.

Option D:  Colonic atresia is the least common type of intestinal atresia. A plain radiograph shows multiple dilated bowel loops, but differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon as seen in the image.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is being evaluated for frequent falls and recurrent sino-pulmonary infections. The image below shows the ocular findings. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of ataxia-telangiectasia.

This child who has frequent falls (gait disturbances), characteristic ocular telangiectasia (seen in the image), and immunodeficiency (recurrent sinopulmonary infections) has ataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11.

Ionizing radiations and free radicals cause breaks in the DNA chain and cause abbarent cross-linking between the same or different strands of DNA. Homologous recombination uses undamaged DNA as a template and repairs the break, leading to the reconstitution of the original sequence. A mutation of the ATM gene is responsible for improper repairing of the breaks of double-strand DNA. Because of this defect, cell response to different pathogenic triggers, such as ionizing radiation and alkylating agents is impaired. Other diseases caused due to similar defects include:

  • Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)
  • Bloom syndrome (BS)
  • Werner syndrome (WS)
  • Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)
  • Breast cancer susceptibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Other human diseases of DNA damage repair:

  • Defective non-homologous end joining repair Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
  • Defective DNA base excision repair MUTYH-associated polyposis  
  • Defective DNA mismatch repair (MMR)Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant was brought to you with hypotonia, a weak cough, and tongue fasciculations. A diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy was made. Which of the following marked regions is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The region marked 1 which shows the anterior horn of the spinal cord is affected in spinal muscular atrophy.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive pattern disease characterized by progressive degeneration of the motor neurons. It results from a continuation of apoptosis that normally occurs in the embryonal period. This results in extensive neuronal degeneration and gliosis of the anterior horns of the spinal cord and brainstem motor nuclei.

Clinically SMA is classified into four types:

  • SMA type I/ Werdnig-Hoffmann disease
  • SMA type II
  • SMA type III/ Kugelberg-Welander disease
  • SMA type IV

SMA type I is seen before the age of six months. Children present with hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, frog-leg posture, and tongue fasciculations. Involvement of the intercostal respiratory muscles causes a paradoxical abdominal breathing pattern and weak cough. Deep tendon reflexes are usually absent. It should be kept as one of the differential diagnoses for floppy infant syndrome.

SMA type II is seen between the age of 6-18 months. Children present with developmental delay, scoliosis, speech, and deglutition problems.

The proximal muscles involving the shoulder girdle are affected in SMA type III. Muscle hypertrophy might be present rather than atrophy.

SMA type IV (adult phenotype) presents with mild muscle weakness in the second or third decade of life. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is testing for SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene deletion/ mutation. Supportive therapy enabling the patient to be maximally functionally independent is the mainstay in management.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presented with ascending left-sided flank pain during micturition and recurrent episodes of urinary tract infections. The urologist suspects vesicoureteric reflux. Which of the following investigations can be done to confirm this condition?

DMSA: Dimercapto succinic acid
questions.solution:
A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) can be done to confirm vesicoureteric reflux.

Vesicoureteric reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder back to the ureter and kidney. The condition is usually congenital and familial. It is more commonly seen in females during evaluation for a urinary tract infection. It predisposes the child to pyelonephritis resulting in renal injury or scarring. This is known as reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy.

The international reflux study (IRS) classification divides it into grades I-V based on the severity as shown below. This is based on the appearance seen in contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

Recurrent urinary tract infections are commonly seen in cases with grade III or IV vesicoureteric reflux. The condition is diagnosed by a voiding cystourethrogram. This is done by catheterization of the bladder followed by instillation of an iodinated contrast. Vesicoureteric reflux done during voiding is known as high-pressure vesicoureteric reflux. A low-dose radiation contrast VCUG provides anatomic information such as a duplex collecting system, ectopic ureter, and bladder diverticulum.

The image below shows dilated ureters seen in a case of vesicoureteric reflux.

Antibiotic prophylaxis and behavioral modification can be used for management. Surgical correction can be done laparoscopically or by the endoscopic route. It should be considered in cases of recurrent acute pyelonephritis despite antibiotic therapy and in the presence of surgically correctable malformations.

Other options:

Option A: A DMSA scan can be done to assess the degree of renal scarring.

Options B and D: An ultrasound and MRI are not required to diagnose vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and bruising around the eyes.  A biopsy image of the adrenal gland tumor picked up on an abdominal CT scan is shown below. Amplification of which of the following oncogenes is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the biopsy are diagnostic of neuroblastoma, in which amplification of the N-MYC gene is seen. 

Neuroblastoma is a tumor arising from the neural crest cells. It is the most common intraabdominal tumor in children. It is associated with the amplification of the N-MYC protooncogene and tumor cell DNA content. These genetic characteristics have prognostic importance. The most common site of occurrence is the adrenal gland. 

Most cases are diagnosed before the age of five. Clinical features of the disease, vary depending on the site of the location of the tumor. It can present as an abdominal mass, periorbital ecchymoses, hypertension, and Horner syndrome. It is also associated with central hypoventilation syndrome, Hirschsprung disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1. 

CT scan will show the presence of tumor calcifications. A biopsy reveals the presence of small round blue cells with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. 

 

Other examples of small, round blue cell tumours include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The treatment modality is chosen based on the patient age and tumor stage. Cytogenetic and molecular features are used to determine the treatment risk group and prognosis for each case. 

Other options:

Option B: C-MYC translocation is associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

Option C: H-RAS point mutations can cause bladder and kidney tumors.

Option D: Point mutations in K-RAS oncogene can result in colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors.

questions.text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. 

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.

Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. 

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.
Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.

Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

A new study shows that children with medulloblastoma who were treated with radiotherapy had better intellectual outcomes when the radiation was delivered as proton beam therapy compared to traditional photon radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text:
Read the pedigree chart and identify the disorder which follows this pattern.

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

MELAS- mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G-6-PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

Other options:

Option A: Gaucher's disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that arises due to the deficiency of β-glucosidase. It is characterized by hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option B: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This leads to the accumulation of galactose and subsequent tissue damage.

The following image depicts autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Option D: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Which of the following is not a component of the triad seen in this syndrome?

choices.text: EEG showing 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves

questions.solution:
Recurrent Infections is not a component of the triad seen in a child with Lennox Gastaut syndrome.

Lennox–Gastaut syndrome typically starts between the age of 2 -10 years. It is associated with de novo mutations, perinatal hypoxia, and trauma. It consists of a triad of

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types such as atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures
  • EEG findings such as 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

The seizures can result in frequent falls and injuries. Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. Clobazam or valproate can be used for drop attacks. In resistant cases, a ketogenic diet, corticosteroids, and intravenous immunoglobulin can be tried.

questions.text: What percentage of children are expected to manifest cystic fibrosis if the father and mother, both are carriers for the disease?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease is likely to be manifested in 25% of children. 

If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes):

  • 25% of the children have normal genotype
  • 50% are carriers
  • 25% are homozygous and hence the disease is manifested

In autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has a homozygous state. Multiple affected members are seen in the same generation. Other generations are not affected. The following pedigree chart depicts an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Cystic fibrosis results due to a defective mutation in the gene encoding for cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR gene). It plays an important role in mucociliary transport along the respiratory mucosa. It also helps regulate the amount of exocrine gland secretion.

The defect in the ion channel results in the production of hyper viscous, adherent secretions which can obstruct the airways. Organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus can grow in the sputum. The exocrine pancreas can undergo fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and acinar tissue loss. The viscid secretions can lead to pancreatic duct obstruction. The flow of digestive enzymes to the duodenum is hence impaired.

Symptoms include sinusitis, steatorrhea, and abdominal pain. Distal intestinal obstruction is a complication due to difficulty in excreting intestinal contents. In neonates, it can present as meconium ileus. 

Detection of high levels of trypsinogen is used in newborn screening. Chloride levels >60mEq/L in the sweat of affected patients are diagnostic. Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis and hypokalemia may also be seen.

Postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators can be used for medical management. The definitive treatment is lung transplantation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with pallor, lethargy, failure to thrive, hypotonia, and developmental delay. Blood tests revealed a megaloblastic picture. Further workup arrives at a diagnosis of Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario diagnosed with Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Imerslund- Grasbeck syndrome/congenital cobalamin malabsorption is an inherited cause of megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 malabsorption in the ileum and consequent vitamin B12 deficiency. It becomes clinically apparent within the 1st 6 years of life. The patient may also have neurologic defects (e.g., hypotonia, developmental delay, brain atrophy, movement disorders, dementia) and non-specific proteinuria.

Patients carry mutations in either CUBN or AMN gene, which code for proteins that form the cubam receptor for the ileal IF-Cbl complex. Since CUBN is also a key receptor for protein reabsorption in the kidney, its impaired expression results in associated proteinuria. Laboratory evaluation indicates low serum cobalamin, hyperhomocysteinemia, methylmalonic acidemia. Early diagnosis and treatment with IM or intranasal cobalamin will reverse the hematologic and neurologic abnormalities, but not proteinuria.

Neurocutaneous disorders are conditions that affect ectodermal derivatives, most commonly the skin and the CNS. 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is due to an autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutation in the NF1 gene. Other characteristic features of NF1 include cafe-au-lait macules, inguinal and axillary freckling, and neurofibromas.

The images below show Lisch nodules, cafe-au-lait macules, and axillary freckling respectively.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by vascular malformations limited to segments. It usually results from a mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene. Leptomeningeal angiomas are a common finding. Presenting complaints in patients range from developmental delay and headaches to seizures, hemiparesis, and stroke-like episodes. Port-wine marks and glaucoma are characteristic.

Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene. Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) also follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other features of TSC also include shagreen patches, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal angiomyolipoma, facial angiofibroma, and periungual fibromas which are shown in the images below. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought to the hospital with poor head control,  hypotonia of the upper limbs, and delayed motor milestones. The mother gives a history of kernicterus in the baby during the early neonatal period. MRI scan of the brain revealed atrophy of the globus pallidus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a child along with MRI finding of atrophy of globus pallidus (in basal ganglia), most likely points to diagnosis of dyskinetic cerebral palsy. 

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a static encephalopathy affecting movement and posture due to non-progressive disturbances occurring in the developing fetal brain. The subtypes of cerebral palsy include:

  • Spastic diplegia
  • Spastic quadriplegia
  • Spastic hemiplegia
  • Dyskinetic cerebral palsy

Dyskinetic/Athetoid/Choreoathetoid/Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. Clinical features include hypotonia with poor head control. Hypertonia with rigidity and dystonia, involuntary movements can develop in the later years. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. MRI scan of the brain reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

Other options:

Option B- Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants due to damage to immature white matter. Periventricular leukomalacia is the most common neuropathologic finding in spastic diplegic patients. Below is the MRI image showing periventricular leukomalacia.

Option C- Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Option D- Spastic hemiplegia is associated with thrombophilic disorders and infections. MRI is more sensitive than CT scan for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A child presents to you with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. Which of the following statement is false about the syndromes associated with this condition?

choices.text: Trisomy 18 can result in cognitive impairment
Aniridia is associated with WAGR syndrome
Male abnormal genitalia is commonly seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
Early-onset renal failure is characteristic of Denys-Drash syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Male abnormal genitalia is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. Both of these are syndromes associated with Wilm's tumor. 

Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children. After neuroblastoma, it is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood. The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor is an incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Pulmonary embolism can be a fatal complication. 

Wilm's tumor arises due to loss of function mutation of the WT1 (Wilm's tumor 1) gene. The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome, Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, Fraiser syndrome, Fanconi anemia, trisomy 18, and Perlman syndrome.

Noteworthy syndromes and their features are:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis / male pseudohermaphroditism
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome: Hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Trisomy 18: Prominent occiput, cognitive impairment, hypertonia

Histologically, Wilms tumor is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. 

Wilms tumor is an example of small, round, blue-cell tumors that are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. Other examples include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy can be used for the management.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

During your neonatal rotation, a final year student asks you to explain the score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. Which among the following is an incorrect statement regarding it?
  1. 1 point is assigned if the baby is pink with blue extremities
  2. 0 points are assigned if the baby is floppy
  3. 2 points are assigned if the pulse is absent 
  4. 1 point is assigned if the respiratory rate is less than 40
  5. 2 points if the baby coughs in response to the insertion of a nasal catheter
questions.solution:
The score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth is the APGAR score, and statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The Apgar score is a method of systematically evaluating newborn infants immediately after birth. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.

Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect because 0 points are assigned if the pulse is absent, and respiratory rate is not used in calculating the APGAR score, but the respiratory effort is considered.

The maximum score is 10 which indicates the fetus is in the best possible condition. Scores of 0-3 require immediate resuscitation, although resuscitation should ideally be started before the  1-minute APGAR score is calculated. 

APGAR score can be used to assess the response to resuscitative efforts and should be calculated every 5 minutes for up to 20 minutes if the 5-minute Apgar score is less than 7.

Causes of Low APGAR scores include:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Analgesics, narcotics, sedatives
  • Airway obstruction (Eg: choanal atresia)
  • Pneumonia and sepsis
  • Previous episodes of fetal asphyxia (recovered)

False-negative APGAR score is when the score is normal, but there is acidosis or high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy last vaccinated at 12 weeks of life presents to you with a high-grade fever, cough, and a rash. The parents say that the rash shown below started from the forehead and behind the ears, and then it spread to the neck and body. Which of the following is true regarding this child's condition?
  1. Causative agent is an RNA paramyxovirus
  2. The secondary attack rate in susceptible contacts is ≥90%
  3. Forchheimer spots are characteristic
  4. Jeryl Lynn strain of vaccine is used for prevention
  5. Most complications are due to secondary bacterial infections.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the symptoms, incomplete vaccination history, and regional distribution of the red maculopapular rash is suggestive of measles. Options 1,2 and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Measles is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash. Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash. They appear as discrete red lesions with bluish-white spots at the level of the premolars. It can also involve the lips and gingiva. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities. The image below shows Koplik's spots.

Confirmation of the diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Management is mainly supportive by the maintenance of hydration and oxygenation. 

Most complications are secondary to bacterial infections. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death and acute otitis media is the most common complication. Croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis are the other complications.

Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition. It is contraindicated in individuals with severe immunosuppression.

Rubella, also known as German measles is a viral disease that presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots are tiny rose-colored lesions or petechial hemorrhages seen on the soft palate. It is usually seen with the onset of the rash. The rash starts on the face and neck and then involves the torso and extremities. It is shown in the image below. 

The Jeryl Lynn strain of virus is used for vaccination against mumps. It is a systemic viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus characterized by parotitis.

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text:
You are educating a group of young mothers at the village health camp about breastfeeding. Which of the following statements are true regarding the components of breastmilk?
  1. Polyunsaturated fatty acids help in nerve myelination.
  2. Lactoferrin has antimicrobial action.
  3. Breast milk is deficient in vitamin C.
  4. Exclusive breastfeeding causes vitamin D deficiency.
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1, 2, and 4.

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in breast milk help in nerve myelination. Lactoferrin helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, and antimicrobial action. Breastmilk is deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented. Breast milk is a rich source of vitamin C and is found in higher levels than in cow milk.

PUFA like docosahexenoic acid (DHA) present in breast milk plays an important role in the growth and nervous system development. Human milk contains taurine and cysteine which are required for neural development. The epidermal growth factor present in breast milk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. The other components present in breast milk are secretory IgA, transforming growth factor, nerve growth factor, platelet-activating factor, bifidus factor, and glutathione peroxidase. Breastmilk has high water content and infants who are exclusively breastfed need not be supplemented with water during their first few months of life. 

The protein content in breast milk is low compared to animal milk. Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk.  Lactose is found in high concentrations in breastmilk and its component galactose is necessary for the formation of galactocerebrosides. It also promotes the growth of lactobacilli. Breastfed infants are at a lower risk of dying from serious gastrointestinal and respiratory illnesses.

Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K and infants have to be supplemented with the same to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: On ultrasound, a fetus was found to have intrauterine growth restriction, with the head circumference relatively preserved compared to length and weight. This type of growth restriction would have occurred due to all of the following causes except
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), which would have been caused by all the above conditions except TORCH infections, which cause symmetric IUGR.

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a deficiency of fetal growth and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as 

Symmetric IUGR:

  • Insult on fetal growth occurs early.
  • As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.
  • It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

  • Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain sparing effect.
  • The Head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.
  • It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases.

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR while late-onset maternal vascular disease(PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old daughter with precocious puberty and bony pain to the clinic. The finding shown in the image below was found on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the clinical features and image showing cafe-au-lait spots is McCune-Albright syndrome.

McCune Albright syndrome presents as a triad of cafe-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. Cutaneous pigmentation is more prominent on the side with severe bone involvement. Fibrous dysplasia is the fibrous replacement of cancellous bone as shown below. It can result in bony pain, repeated fractures, and cranial nerve compression.

The condition arises due to activating mutations of the GNAS1 gene and results in polyendocrinopathy. Precocious puberty is more commonly seen in females with the age of onset between 3-6 years. Neonates can present with Cushing's syndrome due to adrenocortical hyperplasia. Hyperthyroidism, hepatic and cardiovascular involvement are other features.

Cafe-au-lait spots are also seen in neurofibromatosis and Legius syndrome.

Other options 

Option B: Cowden syndrome also known as multiple hamartoma syndrome arises due to a mutation in the PTEN gene. Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, and breast or thyroid malignancies. It is also associated with the development of gastrointestinal polyps. The image below shows facial trichilemmomas.

Option C: Leopard syndrome/ multiple lentigines syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that presents with a generalized symmetric distribution of lentigines. Lentigines are small, dark-brown, and round macules as shown below. Other features include ocular hypertelorism, pulmonary stenosis, and sensorineural deafness. 

Option D: Bloom syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with genomic instability. The clinical features are short stature, photosensitivity, and telangiectatic erythema. It predisposes to the development of childhood leukemia. 

The image below shows the facial appearance seen in the condition.

questions.text: A teacher complains that a 7-year-old girl with falling grades is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increase and her EEG findings show a 3Hz spike and wave discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette and EEG features is typical absence seizures.

Absence seizures are a form of generalized seizures marked by unresponsiveness, staring, and eye flutter which usually last for a few seconds. GABAB receptors, T-type Ca2+ channels, and K+ channels situated within the thalamus are involved in the pathophysiology of absence seizures.

It is of two types:

  • Typical absence seizures  
  • Atypical absence seizures  

Typical absence seizures are associated with 3-Hz spike and slow wave discharges on EEG. It usually starts by the age of 5-8 years and can occur up to a hundred times per day. Hyperventilation can precipitate seizures and EEG changes. They last only for a few seconds and do not have an aura. It can be accompanied by eyelid flutter or upward rolling of the eyes. Simple automatisms such as lip smacking or picking at clothing can also be seen. There is no postictal period and the child usually resumes whatever activity he/she was engaged in prior to the episode. 

Atypical absence seizures are associated with 1-2-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges. Head atonia and myoclonus can also be seen during the seizures. It is precipitated by drowsiness and is generally more difficult to treat. 

Juvenile absence seizures occur at a later stage and are similar to typical absences. It is marked by 4-to-6 Hz spike-and-slow-wave and polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges. It is associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

EEG is the diagnostic test for absence seizures. An MRI would appear normal and so is not useful. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for typical absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is inhibition of T-type calcium channels. Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine have all been associated with aggravation of absence seizures and even absence status epilepticus in children with absence epilepsy.

The following epilepsy syndromes are associated with absence seizures:

  • Childhood absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
  • Myoclonic absence epilepsy
  • Lennox-gestaut syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. It is marked by the rapidity of jerks (<50 mseconds). EEG changes depend on the type of myoclonic seizure.

Option B: Myoclonus is very brief, abrupt, and involuntary jerky contractions of a single muscle or muscle group. Some causes of myoclonus in children include hiccups (physiologic), meningitis, and electrolyte disturbances.  

Option D: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy also known as Janz syndrome is a type of generalized epilepsy seen in young adults. It presents as myoclonic jerks in the morning and generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening. Sleep deprivation and photic stimulation can precipitate the episodes. 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges can be seen on EEG.

questions.text: An anxious mother is worried about feeding her baby. The baby was born at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1.6 kgs. What will you advise as a routine primary feeding method for this baby?
questions.solution:
The nasogastric tube feeding can be advised as a routine primary feeding method for this baby.

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. In this scenario, as the baby is 1.6 kg (low birth weight) and was born at 30 weeks of gestation, nasogastric tube feeding is preferred. Babies born before 32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai feeding can only be used occasionally. Babies born after 34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern and breastfeeding is more preferred.

Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).

LBW can result from preterm birth (born before 37 completed weeks) or IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) or both. Prematurity and low birth weight are the leading causes of neonatal mortality.

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she is noted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes with epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most common lesion expected in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes

Note:

  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia.
  • The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

World Down Syndrome Day is observed annually on March 21, 21st day of 3rd month, signifies trisomy 21. The theme for the year 2023 is "With Us Not For Us", signifying a human rights-based approach where people with disabilities have the right to be treated fairly & have the same opportunities as everyone else, working With others to improve their lives.

A 1-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia presents with hypertension. The infant is diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Which of the following findings will you see in this infant?

(ACTH- Adrenocorticotrophic hormone)
questions.solution:
Decreased androgen levels are seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase enzyme deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is an autosomal recessive disorder where adrenal steroid hormone synthesis is affected. There are many variants of CAH depending on enzyme deficiency. The most common enzyme deficiency is the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. 

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

In the above image, we understand that 17 alpha-hydroxylase is required for the conversion of pregnenolone to 17 hydroxy pregnenolone and progesterone to 17 hydroxy progesterone. Pregnenolone and progesterone are further converted to cortisol and androgens. Therefore deficiency of this enzyme will lead to reduced levels of cortisol and androgens. The accumulated pregnenolone and progesterone lead to increased synthesis of aldosterone.

Patience will present with ambiguous genitalia due to a deficiency of androgens. Excessive aldosterone will lead to increased sodium retention, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Cortisol deficiency stimulates the pituitary and increases ACTH secretion, leading to adrenocortical hyperplasia. The ability to synthesize corticosterone from its precursor deoxycorticosterone is preserved in these patients.

Treatment:

  • It includes glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone to control hypertension by suppressing deoxycorticosterone synthesis. 
  • Removal of intra-abdominal testes or orchidopexy to prevent malignant transformation and appropriate sex hormone replacement therapy at puberty depends on the sex of rearing.

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-month-old infant to a pediatrician for a regular checkup. She tells her baby's weight was approximately double the birth weight at 5 months of age. The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of:
questions.solution:
The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of 1 year.  

Infant weight approximately doubles by the age of 5 months, triples by 1 year, and is 4 times by 2 years of age. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life as a result of excretion of excess extravascular fluid and limited nutritional intake. They regain their birth weight by their 2nd week and thereafter gain weight at specific rates at specific age groups.

The growth and development of a child between the age of 6-12 months can be classified as:

  • Physical Development:  By 12 months of age, birth weight has tripled, length has increased by 50%, and head circumference has increased by 10 cm. A mature pincer grasp occurs and tooth eruption has started to occur. Motor achievements correlate with increasing myelinization and cerebellar growth.
  • Cognitive Development: Object permanence appears by 9 months of age. The baby tries to search for a hidden object.
  • Emotional Development: Infants may cling or cry anxiously when a stranger approaches, demonstrating stranger anxiety. Separation anxiety can also seen.
  • Linguistic Development: Between 8 and 10 months of age, infants produce multisyllabic sounds (“ba-da-ma”) called canonical babbling. Babies can discriminate between languages.

  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the Mentzer index of less than 13, are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

MCV/RBC count also known as the Mentzer index can be used to distinguish thalassemia trait from iron-deficiency anemia. A Mentzer index of more than 13 is suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia while a value less than 13 points to the β-thalassemia trait. 

Prior to the initial blood transfusion, a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) sample must be provided to confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia, which is indicated by the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron-deficiency anemia has a Mentzer index of more than 13. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant who was born at term was presented with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, the infant had a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, and protruding tongue, as shown below. The lower limb x-ray revealed an absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, protruding tongue, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes.

Screening is usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally, and usually, dried blood samples are used for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first, as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based screening.

In untreated hypothyroidism, as the child grows older, there is a discrepancy between chronological age and osseous development. Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. Radiotracer uptake study with radioactive iodine or technetium should be done as soon as primary congenital hypothyroidism is diagnosed.

Treatment with levothyroxine should be started within 2 weeks in order to maintain normal cognitive and physical development. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. 

Other options:

Option A- Down’s syndrome also presents with developmental delay and hypothyroidism. They have characteristic facial features such as a flat face, depressed nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a single palmar crease. The image shown below depicts an infant with Down's syndrome. Radiological features include atlantoaxial dislocation.

Option B-  Congenital rickets is a rare condition resulting from severe maternal vitamin D deficiency and can present with symptomatic hypocalcemia, intrauterine growth retardation, decreased bone ossification along with classic rachitic changes.

Option D- Hurler's syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis which may present after 6 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype:
questions.solution:
In the karyotype, there is a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5, which leads to Cri-du-chat syndrome. Partial aneuploidy occurs as a result of the breakdown of the chromosomes.

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a rare genetic disorder. Features of the condition are hypotonia, short stature, characteristic cry called a cat's cry in the first few weeks of life, microcephaly with protruding metopic sutures, hypertelorism, bilateral epicanthic folds, high arched palate, flat nasal bridge, and intellectual disability.

Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and chromosomal analysis. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is the specific test to confirm the diagnosis. 

Given below is a picture of the facies in cri-du-chat syndrome:

Other options:

Option B: Bloom syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer, and genomic instability.

Option C: Angelman syndrome is caused due to deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It primarily affects the nervous system. Characteristic features are delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.

Option D: Fragile X syndrome is a genetic disorder also termed Martin Bell syndrome. It is the most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among the X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

questions.text: 10-month-old Ishaan was presented to the OPD with a 3-day history of lower respiratory tract symptoms and an expiratory wheeze. Chest X-ray showed mild peribronchial thickening.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition described?

choices.text: The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.
It is more common in children who have not been breastfed.
The mainstay of treatment is antibiotics.
There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchiolitis. The treatment is mainly supportive. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.

It is more common in boys, in those who have not been breastfed, and in those who live in crowded conditions. The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.

Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and antibiotics are not indicated.

There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.text:
Match the following radiographs to the corresponding conditions.

Column A                          Column B

  1. Image 1                  A. Ebstein's anomaly
  2. Image 2                  B. TAPVC
  3. Image 3                  C. Tetralogy of Fallot
  4. Image 4                  D. Transposition of great arteries

TAPVC: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, and 4-B.

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. In supracardiac TAPVC the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. In some cases, there can be massive cardiomegaly resulting in a box-shaped heart. 

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The cardiac silhouette usually has an egg-on-side appearance due to cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum. Normal to increased pulmonary blood flow is also seen. 

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by a tetrad of:
  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as depicted below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is kwashiorkor. The above clinical vignette and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are seen characteristically in kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is the peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy and congested pharynx. Two days later, he develops a maculopapular rash and changes in the tongue and hands as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given is Kawasaki disease. The image shows strawberry tongue and erythema and edema of the hands. 

Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects coronary arteries. It is commonly seen in childhood. Symptoms include cervical lymphadenopathy, pharyngeal congestion, and maculopapular rash.

For the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease, the patient should have a fever for at least 5 days with any four of the following clinical features:

  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival injection
  • Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa 
  • Edema and erythema of the hands and feet
  • Rash
  • Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy

Early diagnosis of the disease is important to prevent coronary artery abnormalities.

Intravenous immunoglobulins are the mainstay of treatment. High-dose aspirin can also be given till the fever subsides. 

Other options

Option A- Erythema infectiosum is caused due to the infection of parvovirus B19. It presents with bright red erythema over the cheeks which gives it a slapped cheek appearance. The patients might also develop a maculopapular rash over the extremities.

Option B- Scarlet fever is caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus and presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, and a bright red rash. The rash appears 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms. It starts on the neck and then extends to the trunk and extremities. The tongue is usually coated and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

Option C- Measles is caused by a paramyxovirus. It presents with fever, rash, exudative conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots. The rash begins on the face and neck and then spreads to the extremities.

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus.  What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain.

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures.

  • Initial blood ph less than 6.7
  • Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score
  • Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing
  • Seizure onset in less than 12 hours
  • Burst suppression pattern in EEG
  • Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion
  • Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours
  • Decerebrate posture

questions.text:
Arrange the following milestones in the order of their development.

1. Sits in the tripod position

2. Waves bye-bye

3. Bidextrous reach

4. 8-10 words vocabulary
questions.solution:
The correct order of development of the milestones given is 3-1-2-4.

Development in a child is the maturation of functions and skills for optimal functioning of an individual. Developmental milestones are easily identifiable events that occur during the developmental process. It is assessed under the following domains.

  • Gross motor
  • Fine motor
  • Personal and social development
  • Language

A baby will reach out for objects with both hands, also known as bidextrous reach by the age of 4 months. It is a key fine motor milestone. 

A child is able to sit with his arms forward for support, known as the tripod position at around 6-7 months. The ability to sit without any support develops by 8 months. It is part of gross motor development. 

By around 9 months, the baby can wave bye-bye. He/she also repeats any activity that can get an appreciative response from the observers. It is a social and adaptive milestone.

By the age of 18 months, the baby has a vocabulary of 8-10 words. By the age of 2, increases to 100 words which can be joined to form simple sentences.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus. His father suffered a similar condition and passed away last year. What is the most likely electron microscopic picture of his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette with a positive family history is suggestive of Alport Syndrome. The most likely electron microscopy of his renal biopsy is the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Other options:

Option A: Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases. 

Option C: Epithelial crescent formation is seen in crescentic RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis etc. Features include oliguria and other signs of nephritic syndrome.

Option D: Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is caused due to immune complex deposition of streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies. Clinical features include malaise, oliguria, and hematuria around 1-2 weeks after a streptococcal infection. The urine is typically described as smoky or cola-colored urine.
