questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a  history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor.   What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The finding of biphasic stridor in this scenario is highly suggestive of congenital subglottic stenosis.

Subglottic stenosis is a congenital or acquired condition characterized by a narrowing of the upper airway extending from just below the vocal folds to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. 

Congenital subglottic stenosis is the most common cause of biphasic stridor in children. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the upper airway in a child. The symptoms of congenital subglottic stenosis usually present shortly after birth and include biphasic stridor, dyspnea, and suprasternal, intercostal, and diaphragmatic retractions. In this child, edema, and secretions caused by the common cold further narrow the subglottic region, leading to the symptoms.  Abnormal cry, aphonia, or hoarseness occur when the vocal cords are affected. In acquired subglottic stenosis, there is a history of laryngeal insult or prior intubation and symptoms appear 3-4 weeks after the same.

Diagnosis is made by airway radiographs and confirmed by direct laryngoscopy. The percentage of stenosis is determined and graded using the Myer Cotton system from grades I through grade IV, indicating the severity.

Management includes dilatation and endoscopic laser surgery for grades 1 and 2 subglottic stenosis, and laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage graft augmentation in grades III and IV subglottic stenosis. Mitomycin C is used in the management of subglottic stenosis post-operatively, in order to prevent re-stenosis.

Other options:

Option A- Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly causing stridor in a child. which typically presents with low-pitched, inspiratory stridor which is exacerbated by crying and agitation.

Option C- Croup is caused by the parainfluenza virus, and typically presents with symptoms of fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness of voice. In severe cases, the child might develop respiratory distress with hypoxia and cyanosis.

Option D- Bilateral vocal cord paralysis can also cause stridor in infants and children. Congenital central nervous system lesions such as Chiari malformations and myelomeningoceles can cause bilateral vocal cord paralysis which leads to respiratory distress, high-pitched inspiratory stridor, and a weak cry.

questions.text: An infant presents with delayed milestones, irritability, seizures, and weak limb movements. On examination, there is macrocephaly, prominent occiput, and bulging fontanelles.  MRI brain is shown below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?

choices.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore
Developmental failure of roof of fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to Dandy-Walker syndrome, in which developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle is seen. The MRI shows a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa.

Dandy-Walker syndrome is a posterior fossa anomaly that includes cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. The clinical features are macrocephaly, prominent occiput, delayed developmental milestones, and cerebellar ataxia. Features of hydrocephalus such as irritability, brisk deep tendon reflexes, seizures, bulging fontanelle, and spasticity are the other clinical manifestations. It can be due to chromosomal abnormalities, teratogen exposure, or single gene disorders. 

Hydrocephalus is a group of conditions that arise due to impaired circulation or absorption of cerebrospinal fluid. In some cases, it can be due to increased production as seen in choroid plexus papilloma. Other causes include congenital aqueduct stenosis, neural tube defects, and posterior fossa malformations.

The image below depicts the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid.

Acetazolamide and furosemide can be used for the medical management of hydrocephalus temporarily. Extracranial shunts such as ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the definitive management. Complications of shunts include occlusion and infections. 

Other options:

Option A: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore produces anencephaly. There is an absence of cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum. Anencephalic infants usually die within a few days of birth.

Option B: Displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the cervical canal produces type 1 Chiari malformations.  Symptoms include headaches, neck pain, urinary frequency, and spasticity. They usually present during late childhood.

The following image shows type 1 Chiari malformations.

Option C: Failure of pontine flexure development during embryogenesis produces type 2 Chiari malformations. Presenting features during infancy include stridor, weak cry, and apnea. During childhood, it can present with spasticity and incoordination.

questions.text:
Which among the following disorders does not follow the classic mendelian inheritance?
  1. Angelman syndrome
  2. Marfan syndrome
  3. Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  4. Prader -Willi syndrome
  5. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, Angelman syndrome (1), Kearns-Sayre syndrome (3), and Prader-Willi syndrome (4) do not follow a classic Mendelian inheritance pattern.

The classic forms of genetic inheritances such as autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked inheritance are referred to as Mendelian inheritance forms.

Autosomal dominant inheritance is marked by the presence of one abnormal gene on one of the autosomes/ chromosomes 1-22. Autosomal recessive inheritance requires both copies of the same to be abnormal. If genes located on the X chromosome are affected, an X-linked pattern of inheritance with males being affected more commonly is seen. 

The non-mendelian inheritance pattern is used to describe mitochondrial inheritance, trinucleotide repeat disorders, and genetic imprinting.

Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome arise due to genetic imprinting. Here, the gene expression depends on the parental origin of the chromosome. It results due to an imbalance in the active copies of a specific gene. In Angelman syndrome, the maternal copy is affected while the paternal one is affected in Prader-Willi syndrome. Both the syndromes present with developmental delays and mental retardation. 

Marfan's syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Features include tall stature, arachnodactyly, lens subluxation, and aortic root dilatation. 

Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder that results in lactic acidosis, pigmentary retinitis, and progressive external ophthalmoplegia. 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder that is characterized by the involvement of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. Calf hypertrophy is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A male baby born at term from uncomplicated delivery develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. The chest x-ray shows a diffuse ground-glass appearance of lung fields. Surfactant replacement and mechanical ventilation fail to improve hypoxemia. There is a history of death of a term male sibling at 1 month of age due to respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of respiratory distress and no response to surfactant therapy in a newborn and a family history of sibling death point toward a diagnosis of neonatal pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).

It is a disorder characterized by intra-alveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant due to abnormal surfactant production or impaired clearance by alveolar macrophages. Inherited PAP occurs due to the dysfunction of various surfactant proteins.

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is classified into primary and secondary PAP. Primary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is caused due to disruption of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signaling. Secondary PAP is caused due to several different diseases that reduce alveolar macrophage number or function.

In the neonatal period, the disease may manifest as a severe respiratory failure whereas in older children it has an insidious onset of chronic interstitial lung disease. Infants present with symptoms of dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis.

Chest x-ray shows diffuse alveolointerstitial infiltrates presenting as ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy is the gold standard investigation to diagnose PAP. Latex agglutination tests for the presence of anti–GM-CSF antibodies in BAL fluid or blood can also be done. They are highly sensitive and specific for the autoimmune forms of alveolar proteinosis.

The disease is progressive and is refractory to surfactant replacement therapy. Neonates with severe respiratory failure require mechanical ventilation and can also be treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. Neonatal intensive care interventions and lung transplantation have been successful in a few cases. A total lung lavage is a therapeutic option for patients with childhood PAP. Subcutaneous or inhaled administration of recombinant GM-CSF may improve pulmonary function in some adults with later-onset PAP. 

Other options:

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) presents immediately after birth, with features of respiratory distress due to aspiration of meconium in utero, resulting in airway obstruction. Most cases improve well with supportive care and mechanical ventilation. 

Option C: Hyaline membrane disease occurs in premature infants due to surfactant deficiency. Distress ensues within a few minutes of birth. If untreated, it may result in respiratory failure. Surfactant replacement therapy and mechanical ventilation will greatly improve the condition.

Option D: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is self-limiting tachypnea occurring in full-term infants due to reduced clearance of fetal lung fluid. Treatment is mainly supportive.

questions.text:
Match the following metabolic derangements with their most likely presentations -
  Metabolic derangement   Clinical presentation
A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency 1. Splenomegaly, avascular necrosis, and delayed puberty
B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency 2. Copious nasal discharge, corneal clouding, dysostosis multiplex
C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency 3. Hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, doll-like facies
D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase 4. Extreme irritability, developmental delay, optic atrophy
    5. Hepatomegaly, vomiting, cataracts, and sepsis
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-2, and D-5.

A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is seen in Von Gierke disease which is a glycogen storage disorder (Type Ia). Patients with GSD Type I present with a protruding abdomen due to hepatomegaly, doll-like facies, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, organomegaly, seizures, and pulmonary hypertension. It is an autosomal recessive disorder 

B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe's disease which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase. The classic manifestations that would suggest Krabbe's disease include irritability, seizures, and hypertonia.  Optic atrophy and developmental delay are other features.

C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency is seen in Hurler syndrome,  a type of mucopolysaccharidosis type I.  Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex. Corneal clouding, short stature, and copious nasal discharge are other features.

D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency is seen in classical galactosemia. Clinical features include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and sepsis. They also tend to develop cataracts.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with short stature and mental retardation. She also has coarse facial features and delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development. Evaluation of the thyroid reveals elevated TSH, low T4, and atrophic thyroid on ultrasonography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myxedematous endemic cretinism is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

Children with myxedematous endemic cretinism present with mental retardation, short stature, coarse facial features, deafness, delayed skeletal maturation, delayed sexual development, and no goiter. Serum TSH is elevated while serum T4 levels are low and ultrasonography shows atrophic thyroid.

Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can be neurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. Both neurologic and myxedematous types can manifest neurologic symptoms. Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectual development. Iodine deficiency is also associated with poor school performance in children and recurrent pregnancy loss in women.

Iodine deficiency can be best prevented by using iodized salt and oils. The recommended daily intake of iodine is 40-120 μg for children up to the age of 10 years, and 150 μg for older children and adults. An additional intake of 25 μg and 50 μg is recommended during pregnancy and lactation, respectively.

Other options:

Option B: Neurological cretinism is characterized by deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity and rigidity. Goiter is seen in neurological cretinism. In neurological cretinism skeletal and sexual maturation remains unaffected. Disorders of stance and gait with preservation of vegetative functions, signs of cerebellar or oculomotor disturbance and severe mental deficiency. Myxedematous cretinism is characterized by retarded psychomotor development, severe short stature, coarse facial features and myxedema without deaf-mutism.

Option C: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goiter, ophthalmopathy, and dermopathy (no mental retardation).

Option D: Pendred syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride–iodide transporter in the thyroid and cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goiter and sensorineural hearing loss.
